Best to look at the up down position as a circle and your just viewing it from the side so it appears to only go up and down.  Everything is circular in nature.  So really there are many more usable positions than it would appear from just a single plane of view.  The in-between point will have different phase and position corresponding to which quadrant it is in.  For instance, the top two: (+,+), (+,-) and bottom two: (-,+), (-,-), which when viewed from the side would appear identical (top-top or bottom-bottom) no matter which quadrant it is in at the time, then your standard (1) or (-1) which exist outside this inner core and at the furthest point in either direction so as to not have a +/- side but only an absolute neutral which becomes your 1 or 0.

This video (like all other YouTube videos on the subject) does not answer the central question "How Does a Quantum Computer Work?"
i.e. It does not explain how to do a controlled collapse of the wave functions of the qubits in such a way that the resulting classical bits correspond to the computation you want done, rather than some completely random answer.

To take a trivial example, if you want to make (say) a 2-input logic gate, you would have two logical inputs, and two entangled qubits, which can simultaneously encode a superposition of the four possible output states.
How do you "teach" the qubits which classical states they should collapse into for which combinations of classical logical inputs?
i.e. to configure them to behave like an XOR gate, rather than say an AND gate, or an OR gate.

PS: I don't mind an answer in the form of equations, so long as you use plain English to describe the mathematical-notation of any operators you use.

At 0:34, the narrator said "This single phosphorus atom is embedded in a silicon crystal right next to a tiny transistor."

Question 1: Via what kind of technology can you "pick up / split out" just 1 single phosphorus atom? Not to mention "to embed this single phosphorus atom into other material".

Question 2: "(sitting) right next to a tiny transistor?" Does this mean that this piece of silicon has been gone through all the complicated processing as any functional IC chip does? (Although in this case only 1 tiny transistor has been made)

Then how can you be sure that there is no "unwanted foreign material", that were brought in unavoidably during the processing, sticking around these 2 entities (that is, the single 1 phosphorus atom and the single 1 tiny transistor)?

Question 3: And what is that tiny transistor for? I guess you want to use it as an amplifier to create some kind of electrical current signal output. But you have not set up the so-called DC bias-level properly so that the tiny Transistor can work as an amplifier. Just because you put the signal source next to a transistor is not enough to convince the transistor to do the amplifying job for you.

Question 4: Based on the element periodic table, every phosphorus atom has 15 electrons circling around its nucleus. How can you be sure your magnetic field wave drives not only always just one electron, but also always the very same one electron, among those 15 electrons? How about the other 14 electrons belong to this same phosphorus atom? How about the numerous electrons belong to all the other silicon atoms as well as those atoms of the tiny transistor? None of those electrons will be stimulated by your magnetic field wave frequency?

Question 5: A piece of silicon chip can generate detectable output signal just because 1 single electron embedded inside that silicon chip changes its spin direction? I just can not swallow this, no matter who claims so.

In another video, you commented that instant long-range communication using qubits was impossible because we can't write to them, but it seems from this video that we can. If we can, seems like a pretty straightforward matter. Well, not in practice yet, but still.

Make an array of, let's say, 64 qubits, and another with its entangled pairs. Place them in devices A and B capable of measuring and changing spins. Hook it up to a classical computer. Make initial measurement of the entire array in A and assign all measured spins a value of 0. Their exact opposites are 1, and 0 in machine B. You now have a pair of entangled qubit arrays with the same representation of data, and flipping qubits on one end will instantaneously transmit it to the other.

My knowledge of this is superficial at best and there's probably some other reason why it wouldn't work, but it seems theoretically doable to me, if we can flip them along with just measuring them.

They design the system so that it is not observed until the calculation is complete. So once the answer is reached, then it is read off.

Working with qubits instead of regular bits give you more powerful operations. To put it simply, you may get the results as 0 or 1 but you will get it faster. Most quantuum algorithms are based on what is called superposition - this is like having all the inputs of an algorythm. Then you run your algorythm on this set of data (all the inputs at once!) and you'll get your result. The downside is that your result is probabilistic - for example the RSA breaking algo has a ~50% success rate.

The reading is up or down, that's true. But you don't have to read to make the calculation (that is to say, the qubit manipulation), and that's the beauty of this. You do the calculations in a black box without looking at the intermediate results and when you combine everything you have the answer that you're looking for. It sounds a bit like magic but with the right algebra it is very elegant yet still a bit weird.

Air is denser than helium, and gravity pulls stronger on things with higher density. This is because higher density means more mass per unit volume, causing a larger "bend", if you will, in space-time (which is essentially gravity). It's not that the balloon is being repelled, but that air is being pulled down by gravity STRONGER than the balloon is being pulled down, therefore causing the balloon to rise. (cont 3) you will know that the logical function is either the AND gate, or one of 3 other possible logical functions which have a single 1 in their truth table (a AND with one or the other or both (NAND) its inputs inverted). Now you set the inputs of the function to 1,1 to check if it's indeed an AND (you should get a 1 on the oscillioscope) and you're done, with just 2 operations (if you could the number of times you need to change the input) instead of the classical 4.

(cont 2) You set it such that both inputs to the function are 50% 1 and 50% 0.  If it is indeed an AND gate, then only one of the 4 possible combination (1,1) produces a 1, so if you did discrete measurements of the output of this system, 25% of the time you should get a 1, otherwise 0. I think on the oscilloscope which does a continuous measurement this would show up as a potential a quarter of the way between 0 and 1. Now if indeed you see that output on the oscilloscope (cont 3..)

(cont 1) Now suppose you start off knowing only that the computation this system performs is one of the 16 possible logical functions on two bits. You want to check if it is indeed the AND function. Classically you need 4 measurements with different inputs (the combinations of either the nucleus or the electron being flipped). In this system however you can set both the nucleus and the electron into a superposition of being flipped or not (vector pointing sideways instead of up/down) (cont 2..)

Yes, and I think even with this basic experiment you can show a simple computation that it performs in fewer steps than can be done classically. Take whether you flip the electron or the nucleus as two binary inputs to a logical function and the measurement you get on the oscilloscope as the output. The output is only 1 (high potential) when both are flipped. This corresponds to a logical AND gate. (cont..)

For a very simple example of a quantum algorithm search for the Deutsch's algorithm. It does not give the most amazing computational advantage, but it's a very nice and easy to understand example of something that a quantum computer can do and a classical computer cannot.

A quantum computer is faster for very special tasks only. The number of known quantum algorithms is very reduced. The main idea of all these algorithms is that you create a quantum superposition of diferent inputs, you operate over this superposition (so, in principle, you have information about the answer for ALL the  diferent inputs at the same time) and then you make specific quantum operations that steers the result towards the right final state, then you measure.

You cannot measure the superposition, because measurement takes the electron out of superposition and forces it into either state. That is why Qbits are no better than classical bits for storage and many other purposes: The number of measurable states for a collection of n qbits is 2^n, just like it is with classical bits. Superposition only comes into play in the internal calculations of the quantum computer.

Essentially, if you imagine n bits, a traditional computer can be in one of 2^n possible states at any time, and can switch between them at a fixed clock speed. So no matter how many bits the processor uses, it can only be in one state at a time. 
The difference with a quantum computer with n qbits is that, because of the way superposition works, that processor can be in 2^n states at the same time, and so processing time is effectively sped up by a factor of 2*n.

In the computer you are sitting on right know there is probably some kind of real time clock somewhere on your motherboard. 
It simply counts a certain value up in a known frequency and is kept running when the computer is of by a little battery.
They use some kind of crystal oscillator (wikipediaDOTorg/wiki/Crystal_oscillator) to generate electric impulses in a known frequency. The computer then reads this count and converts it to local time so that it can display it.
